column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=It will
#Text=be readily seen that night-time is the most
#Text=favourable for the retention of scent, as
#Text=evaporation does not take place so rapidly
#Text=then, and this, of course, as I have shown,
#Text=is why dogs are more especially useful at this
#Text=time.
#Text=It is even possible to track a fairly
#Text=recent trail on certain roads at night in spite
#Text=of the hard surface, and a quite recent trail
#Text=on pavement, always supposing these have
#Text=not been fouled too much by other footsteps.
#Text=Strongly scented ground makes tracking
#Text=difficult, as the animal or human scent is
#Text=overpowered : thus clover fields, or any
#Text=highly scented crops, and manured fields,
#Text=are decided drawbacks.
#Text=Newly ploughed fields are unprofitable
#Text=tracking-ground, the reason being that the
#Text=turned - up earth has a strong aromatic
#Text=odour of its own, apart from that of the
#Text=chemicals, &c., that may have been previously put into it.
#Text=Now with regard to the scent left by a
#Text=man, much interesting speculation arises as
#Text=to whether the dog works entirely by foot
#Text=scent, or if he depends as well on body scent,
#Text=and if so, how much.
#Text=As yet, all experiments by experts have not to any extent
#Text=given us a decided answer on this point.
#Text=I here give an account of some interesting
#Text=experiments which Dr Romanes carried out.
#Text=“ On one occasion Dr Romanes put a most
#Text=intelligent bitch to a crucial test.
#Text=He
#Text=walked for fifty yards in his ordinary
#Text=shooting-boots ; then he walked a hundred
#Text=yards in his stockings, and completed another hundred yards on his bare feet.
#Text=The
#Text=bitch followed the first part of the trail
#Text=at full speed
#Text=.
#Text=“ Changing the experiments, he soaked
#Text=his ordinary shooting - boots with oil of
#Text=aniseed, and walked with these over the
#Text=park.
#Text=Strange to say, this strong odour
#Text=did not interfere with the bitch’s scent,
#Text=for it ran him down as quickly as before
#Text=.
#Text=“ Accordingly, this keen observer came to
#Text=the conclusion that his setter distinguished
#Text=his trail from that of all others by the
#Text=peculiar smell of his boots, and not by the
#Text=particular scent of his feet or body.
#Text=The
#Text=exudations from his feet required to be combined with shoe-leather, and brown paper
#Text=can stop the transmission of that scent.”
#Text=I give the above quotation with all due
#Text=deference to such a renowned authority ;
#Text=but I myself, from my own experiments,
#Text=am not prepared to accept, without
#Text=reserve, all he says, as my experience goes
#Text=to show that a trail run in stockinged feet,
#Text=or bare feet, is more favourable for tracking
#Text=than that run in boots.
#Text=My own opinion
#Text=is, that the dog goes both by foot scent
#Text=on the ground and also by body scent,
#Text=when this latter scent is there, and I think
#Text=that this is another reason why tracking
#Text=in the evening or at night is so much easier
#Text=for the dog.
#Text=The air at this time being
#Text=both moist and still, the fugitive’s body
#Text=scent remains suspended in the air as he
#Text=goes along, and this is a great additional
#Text=aid to the dog.
